U: unknown; NR: not reported; * sample used for 13C; † date of birth; ‡ omitted for not being among our target information δ13C and δ15N versus diet and geolocation Less negative values of δ13C found in teeth and body tissues are mainly related to the consumption of foods such as C4 plants (maize and sugar cane) and marine resources (LEE -THORP, 2008, p.) . This variation, in turn, is intrinsically linked to cultural differences and geographic location, given the regional variation on species frequency in relation to C3 plants, such as rice, and other edible vegetables, other than maize and sugarcane, with more negative values of δ13C (BENSON et al., 2006b; KING There is an overlap of δ13C values in diets rich in C4 plants and diets rich in marine animals, and for this reason, combined analysis of carbon and nitrogen is productive for diet reconstruction. Levels of 15N vary according to the position of the individual in the food chain, increasing at each trophic level. By combining analyzes of δ13C and δ15N it is possible to differentiate diets based on C4 plants from diets rich in marine animals, solving the doubt generated by the overlapping of carbon values between these food sources (BASTOS et al., 2015; KING et al., 2013; REGAN, 2006) . However, the insertion of food items from other places and dissemination of fast food chains will reduce the differences between regions, as agreed by Alkass et al. (ALKASS et al., 2011, 2013) , Kamenov et al.(KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017) and Someda et al.(SOMEDA et al., 2016) , that researched contemporary samples of donated teeth. However, none of the authors collected information on individual dietary profile to include as analyzed variable, which could have been done, with a live sample, except for Someda et al.(SOMEDA et al., 2016) , who worked with a sample of teeth from the Tokyo Dental College Library.

Instead, gastronomic cultural patterns of the studied groups were considered as a possible justific ation for the outcomes (ALKASS et al., 2011, 2013; KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017; SOMEDA et al., 2016) , such as a higher maize consumption – a C4 plant – in USA and Mexico (ALKASS et al., 2011, 2013) , and higher rice consumption, a C3 plant, with short presence of maize among Japanese (SOMEDA et al., 2016) . The assumptions made about diet can be reasonable when dealing with a large sample, which is not the case of these studies, as seen in Table 3.

In Alkass et al.(ALKASS et al., 2011) , the authors propose a compa rison between groups from different countries, but with a high risk of sampling bias. The irregular distribution of the sample can be confirmed by the inclusion of individuals from seven different countries, but in four of them, a single person was studied . Also, teeth with plastic or mercury alloy filling were included, which is not yet proven to be safe for the accuracy and precision of the method. Hanc et al. (HANĆ; OLSZEWSKA; BARAŁKIEWICZ, 2013) have shown that some elements migrate from dental material to enamel and dentin, reducing the reliability of filled teeth for this kind of research. The mean age of the sample is 40 ± 26 years, with subjects from 17 to 98 years old, using all dental elements from central incisor to third molar. This design was appropriate for age estimation, the main objective of the study. However, when searching isotopes from dental enamel of all teeth aiming to study diet and geographic variations, one is looking to the diet window from 0 to 20 years old. Changes along the grow ing process were not considered on the discussion, that resumes the results of δ13C in one single paragraph. In Alkass et al.(ALKASS et al., 2013) there is the same bias, and the mean age of the sample is 42 ± 18.9 years, extending from 10 to 95 years. The main objective of the author, and most widely explored in the results and discussion was age estimation. Dietary differences should be considered, and the author cites difference in the δ13C levels between enamel and dentin, suggesting a feeding differenc e between childhood and adolescence, but with this age group in the sample, and using all dental elements, the presence of secondary dentin was not considered at the root levels, and the authors also ignored the mineralization chronology, ranging from 0 (first molar’s occlusal top) to 20 years (third molar’s apex), which is even affected by the mother’s diet during breastfeeding.

The studies of Gregorika et al.(GREGORICKA et al., 2017) and Henderson et al.(HENDERSON; LEE -THORP; LOE, 2014) used archaeologi cal samples, accessing the levels of δ13C and δ18O to explore the origin of six individuals with different burial treatment (GREGORICKA et al., 2017) , and levels of δ13C and δ15N in 10 horizontal strips in different teeth to explore the evolution and changes in alimentary habits. The authors found that the six individuals had statistically homogeneous values with the rest of the population, suggesting isotopically similar sources, and that the individuals had different burial treatment not by ethnic or physical differences. The authors propose future studies with δ15N, since the consumption of marine fish is isotopically similar to C4 plant values, generating mistaken reconstruction of the diet.

Henderson et al.(HENDERSON; LEE -THORP; LOE, 2014) research ed δ13C and δ15N isotopes for the reconstruction of the diet, using from the first dental elements to be formed on breastfeeding ages to the third molar, which ends its formation in youth. The values of 13C found are consistent throughout the whole period , suggesting no significant change in diet from childhood to maturity. When observing the δ15N values, however, the first molars showed significant oscillation, with peak at 0 to 6 months representing breastfeeding, and decline at 3 to 4 years, consistent with the insertion of non-maternal milk. Second molars have shown, after a decline in 15N during earlier childhood, a steady increase in 15N during the later childhood, from approximately 8-9 years, to the teenage years, followed by a general upward trend facing adulthood, as shown by third molars.

Henderson et al.(HENDERSON; LEE -THORP; LOE, 2014) found no significant age effect for 13C, unlike the 15N which shows a highly significant age effect. This paper, the only one in the selected studies that tested δ15N, makes a difference in the interpretation of all other papers that used δ13C searching for diet differences, reminding that the protein source can affect δ13C levels, since fish and marine sources mimic C4 plants. Hence, to access diet differences or reconstruct their characteristics, δ13C and δ15N must be considered together (DUPRAS; TOCHERI, 2007; FULLER; RICHARDS; MAYS, 2003) .
87Sr/86Sr versus provenance

Strontium isotopes present in bones and teeth are directly related to the geological formation of their place of residence at the time of tooth or tissue formation, being isotopes widely used for studies of provenance. Rocks have a ratio of 87Sr/86Sr directly proportional to their age, permitting a relationship with the study of the soil from which comes the food and water ingested by a given individual (BASTOS et al., 2015; KING et al., 2013; LEE -THORP, 2008) .

Among the two studies eligible for this review, the ratio of 87Sr/86Sr was the only objective in Juarez (JUAREZ, 2008) , presented as a preliminary research, with a sample of nineteen Mexicans from four different states. Kamenov et al. (KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017) included Sr in the multi -isotopic analysis of twelve Bulgarians, together with 13C, 18O, and three Pb isotopic ratios (206Pb/204Pb, 207Pb/204Pb, and 208Pb/204Pb). Both articles highlight the primary influence of geological patterns and local water for the establishment of Sr isotopic varia tion, with expected differences between inland and coastal areas, typically geologically younger. However, when dealing with modern populations, it is necessary to consider cultural differences in food preparation and consumption, together with globalizati on and spreading of distribution networks in different regions, including the incorporation of fast foods chains. To that end, the authors of both studies concluded that rock or water -based mapping is not enough for georeferencing modern humans, and a database of Sr levels from different regional groups is the best forensic reference for human identification.
18Oand δ2H versus geolocation

The 18O levels observed in the teeth are related to water ingested directly or by food and its values and varies according to factors such as latitude, altitude and distance from the ocean. However, three of the four studies with contemporary samples (ALKASS et al., 2013; KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017; WARNER et al., 2018) agree that the equation generated by local geological mapping from potable water is not sufficient as a reference for comparison with human tissue. Also, for oxygen, the portion of the diet composed of water may have non-local origin and alter the observed isotopic levels, making it necessary for human identification a joint comparison of local drinking water and population values previously evaluated.

Warner et al.(WARNER et al., 2018) , who tested only this isotope in a sample of the Mississippi and surrounding areas, against refined isoscape, agree on the need to develop equations that allow the conversion of tap water values for human tissue comparisons. As in the other selected studies, the authors agree that multiple stable and radiogenic isotopes, along with trace elements should be used in conjunction when developing an isotopic profile and narrowing human provenance.

Someda et al.(SOMEDA et al., 2016) proposes a comparison between Japanese and Americans, showing a broader range of 18O in US than in Japan and reflecting America’s larger geographical area, with more climate and geological variations. In Gregorika et al.(GREGORICKA et al., 2017) , the only selected study with archaeological sample, 18O was one of the elements used to compare the tissue levels of six individuals with different burial treatment, as cited above, finding values isotopically close to the group range.

Holobinko et al.(HOLOBINKO et al., 2011) was the only paper in the sample that analyzed 2H in tooth enamel, since, according to the authors, this isotope is currently searched in hair, nails and bone collagen as reference of human geolocation, but enamel had not been used. After trying different methodologies in archaeological and modern samples, the authors have found no significant differences in δ2H values, meaning it cannot yet be used for geographical origin research.

DISCUSSION Teeth, along with fingerprints and the iris, represent one of the parts of the body that is unique among individuals. However, because of their long resistance to thermal and taphonomic destruction, they become, together with the bones, primary pieces in the search for individual information in an archaeological or forensic context. Several studies have established reference patterns for inferring about age (CAMERIERE et al., 2008) , ancestry (TINOCO et al., 2016) , sex (MARTINS FILHO et al., 2016) , stature (REKHI et al., 2014) , diet profile, parafunction, lifestyle, among other important and valid characteristics for human identification or archaeological interpretation (AZEVEDO et al., 2014; BRKIC; MILICEVIC; PETROVECKI, 2006; KOUSSOULAKOU; MARGAR ITIS; KOUSSOULAKOS, 2009) .

One of these evaluation methods considers the isotopic variation of tissue elements, and relates them to the time of tissue formation, allowing a reading of different periods in the past, geolocation and nutritional profile. Cons idering the time of formation of the teeth, and the fact that they are the only tissues in the body that are never remodeled, every individual carries in his oral cavity a record of his childhood and adolescence. This information has been accessed by arche ology since its earliest discoveries almost 50 years ago and are used for studying the characteristics of past groups, including factors such as lifestyle, residential mobility, migratory flow, cultural and food preferences, famine periods, and more (BEAUM ONT et al., 2013; BEAUMONT; MONTGOMERY, 2016; DE MASI, 2009a; EERKENS et al., 2014; KILLGROVE; MONTGOMERY, 2016) ; however, the method can be applied by any area in which it has relevance, from forensic anthropology to nutrition, physical education, medicin e, and nursing.

The results of the present study show a still incipient presence of studies about isotopic analysis in teeth among the forensic literature, in contrast to the marked presence of isotopic studies in archaeological literature. The greater activity in the last 5 years, among the 10 years surveyed – six (ALKASS et al., 2013; GREGORICKA et al., 2017; HENDERSON; LEE -THORP; LOE, 2014; KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017; SOMEDA et al., 2016; WARNER et al., 2018) of the nine papers selected – shows movement in the recent discovery of latent potential of the method for human identification; and, among the excluded titles, even if out of the proposed search, we would expect to see future exploration of this potential in the medical area (BALTER et al., 2015; HATCH e t al., 2006; MEW; YUDKOFF; TUCHMAN, 2014) .

All the selected studies that used contemporary samples emphasized the impact of food profile on isotopic values, and the need to observe the globalization of food flow, fast food chains and imported edible items. However, no study collected data on the sample’s diet, which could narrow the understanding of outliers and different group values.

One must also consider on results interpretation and on sampling criteria, the dental elements included in the sample, and their mineralization chronology, to keep in mind the interval being studied. Permanent teeth begin to form in a regular rhythm and time studied by dental anthropology, representing a period of about 20 years from the formation beginning of first molar until the conclusion of third molar, the last tooth to be formed (CAMERIERE; FERRANTE; CINGOLANI, 2006; SANTIAGO et al., 2018) .

This time range was correctly considered in Henderson et al.(HENDERSON; LEE - THORP; LOE, 2014) , who used horizontal strips distributed longitudinally in the different elements to interpret the diet variation from early childhood – including the influence of maternal diet during the breastfeeding period – until maturity. When analyzing isotopes from root dentin, it is necessary to consider the age range in the sampling since the tooth is formed with primary dentin, but produces secondary dentin inside, slowly and continuously narrowing the root canal (AZEVEDO et al., 2014; CAMERIERE et al., 2013) . Therefore, when analyzing denti n from individuals after adulthood, the isotopic values will have dietary variables from childhood or adolescence, depending on the dental element, but diet in adulthood can be an issue. Therefore, a broad age range for these studies is not appropriate for the study design. The relationship between dietary changes and δ13C levels was clearly observed, but the consideration of alimentary habits in a cultural rough estimation reduces the potential of the outcomes. The insertion of fast-food, imported supplies and glocalization of products must be observed in a specific and measured way (MARTINELLI et al., 2011; VALENZUELA et al., 2012) , so that it is used reliably. Yet on the nutritional profile, Henderson et al. (HENDERSON; LEE -THORP; LOE, 2014) showed how the δ15N values diverge in different phases of the life of the individuals surveyed, with little variation of the values of δ13C. The joint observation of the δ13C and δ15N values for diet patterns interpretation minimizes the risk of observation bias due to the similarity between C4 plants and marine fauna (GRAGNANI et al., 2014) .

The values of δ18O and 87Sr/86Sr in enamel are more closely correlated to drinking water and soil composition, respectively, but also influenced by diet and consumption of external foods. The authors who have researched these isotopes (JUAREZ, 2008; KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017) agree that the variation among the population is mainly based on the place of origin, which does not necessarily follow political boundaries.

All selected studies using contemporary samples conclude that drinking water, soil composition and dietary habits are determinants of isotopic levels of human tissues, but an updated multi -isotope database of the local population allows refining the search and improving the outcomes, in a forensic context of human identification. The proposed subject shows great potential for human identification, and new studies are recommended in order to isotopically map population groups, investing in a well-defined and uniform methodological standard, so that the comparison between groups can be more effective.

CONCLUSIONS The present study has verified the still incipient presence of isotopic analysis in teeth among the forensic literature, with geographic origins as the aim of eight of the nine selected studies. Levels of δ13C was the most frequently researched isotope, relating diet patterns and geolocation. However, the variables to be considered are not totally clear in some of the selected papers, being age and diet profile one of the variables just generically reported, and not controlled or measured. Future research must invest in multi - isotopically mapping population groups, providing methodological standardizing, so that the comparison between groups is accurate, and available as an auxiliary method for human identifica tion.
8 MATERIA IS E MÉTODO S
8.1 ASPECTOS ÉTICOS

O encaminhamento do projeto ao Comitê de Ética precedeu ao início do trabalho, e foi realizado via Plataforma Brasil, e então direcionado pelo sistema ao Comitê de Ética em Pesquisa do Centro de Filosofia e Ciências Humanas da Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro. O projeto foi aprovado pelo parecer número 1.561.481 (Anexo 1).
8.2 AMOSTRA SELECIONADA

Foram selecionadas as regiões metropolitanas de Brasília, Florianópolis e Rio de Janeiro (Figura 1 1) para funcionarem como pontos de coleta das amostras desta pesquisa, pelos motivos expostos em seguida. Brasília despertou interesse por sua localização afastada do litoral, o que mostraria diferenças especialmente no que tange ao oxigênio por conta da continentalidade, e ao estrôncio, uma vez que esta cidad e apresenta características geológicas distintas das encontradas no litoral sul e sudeste do país. Diferenças ambientais, assim como nas fontes e práticas alimentares, também podem fornecer dados do carbono e nitrogênio distintos em Brasília, quando compar ado com as demais localidades selecionadas. Florianópolis reúne grande número de sítios arqueológicos já estudados, inclusive com dieta reconstruída via análise isotópica, permitindo maior contribuição do modelo objetivado. Rio de Janeiro também contém uma variedade de sítios arqueológicos de interesse, e foi selecionada por conveniência, e por se tratar de mais uma cidade no litoral, afastada consideravelmente de Florianópolis (744km em linha reta, e cerca de 1.000km pela malha rodoviária local) para serem esperadas diferenças nos resultados.
de Janeiro e Florianópolis (Google Maps).

Em cada cidade -alvo foram feitos contatos com cirurgiões -dentistas, prof essores de Cirurgia e Traumatologia Buco -Maxilo -Facial, para que atuassem como colaboradores. Aos profissionais que se dispuseram a colaborar após exposição do projeto em conferência remota, foi enviado um kit para coleta de material contendo: instruções por escrito ( Apêndice A ) reforçando o que havia sido explicitado oralmente e instruindo a coleta do material; cópia do parecer consubstanciado do Comitê de Ética em Pesquisa, como comprovante da aprovação do projeto; um folheto ilustrado com explicações sobre a pesquisa e convite à participação (Apêndice B ) para consulta dos pacientes; cópias do Termo de Consentimento Livre e Esclarecido ( Apêndice C ) e do questionário a serem preenchidos pelos participantes (Apêndice D ); e envel opes plásticos adesivados e etiquetados para receberem os dentes doados.

De cada cidade supracitada a amostra objetivada era de 30 indivíduos, porém, de acordo com critérios de inclusão e exclusão explanados em seguida, o número de dentes recebidos foi d iferente do pretendido, ainda que se tenha buscado trabalhar com números similares nas três cidades, sem prejudicar a homogeneidade de cada um dos três grupos. Ressalta -se aqui que a extração dos dentes doados já constava em plano de tratamento elaborado p elos profissionais, sem qualquer conhecimento ou participação d os autores , e os indivíduos se tornavam potenciais sujeitos da pesquisa apenas após decisão pela exodontia, momento em que era lhes apresentado o projeto, através de Termo de Consentimento Livr e e Esclarecido, e oferecida a participação voluntária. Manteve -se, portanto, fiel cumprimento dos termos das Resoluções 466/12 (CONSELHO NACIONAL DE SAÚDE, 2012) , e 118/12 (CONSELHO FEDERAL DE ODONTOLOGIA, 2012) .

Para a amostra, foram considerados os segu intes critérios de inclusão: • Indivíduos brasileiros, de ambos os sexos, a partir de 14 anos de idade, com exodontia em seu plano de tratamento, que aceitaram participar da pesquisa, ou, para os menores de idade, cujo responsável concordou com sua inclusão na amostra, através de Termo de Consentimento Livre e Esclarecido, apresentado no Apêndice C ; • Indivíduos nascidos e residentes nas regiões metropolitanas (casos de mudança residencial descritos em seguida) das cidades do Rio de Janeiro (RJ), Brasília (DF) e Florianópolis (SC), que pudessem fornecer informações sobre sua infância e adolescência , de acordo com questionário descrito em seguida; e • Dentes molares, à exceção do primeiro, sem tratamento endodôntico (tratamento de canal), preferencialmente hígidos , isto é, íntegros, ou, se restaurados, em não mais que duas faces.

Os participantes que declararam ter migrado de suas cidades de origem foram excluídos da amostra principal, mas todos os elementos dentários recebidos foram mantidos em poder dos pesquisa dores, e analisados quanto à possível inclusão parcial na amostra, como será descrito adiante. Estes dentes foram recebidos juntamente com os demais, pois no contato com os cirurgiões -dentistas colaboradores, procurou -se onerá -los o mínimo possível, uma ve z que já estariam aceitando aumentar em sua carga de trabalho algumas tarefas necessárias à colaboração com o projeto. Desta forma, as instruções para seleção se restringiram à idade do paciente, e elemento dentário extraído. O primeiro molar foi excluído da amostra pois sua formação possui maior número de variáveis, dado que a coroa é mineralizada entre 0 e 3 anos de idade, aproximadamente (HILLSON, 1996) , o que coloca a dieta materna e idade de desmame como fatores determinantes nos valores isotópicos de esmalte e dentina. Outras razões de sua eliminação da amostra consideram que a necessidade de exodontia do primeiro molar permanente ocorreria apenas em casos de grande destruição tecidual deste elemento – o mais frequentemente acometido por cárie na popu lação, por ser comumente confundido com um dente decíduo dentre a população leiga (COSER et al., 2005) . Assim, também por razões conhecidas pela Odontologia Social, esperava -se que o terceiro molar ocupasse grande parte, se não toda a amostra, por ser o el emento com maior probabilidade de ser extraído hígido, por ausência de espaço no arco dental.
8.3 QUESTIONÁRIO APLICADO

Todos os indivíduos que aceitaram participar responderam a um Questionário sobre Dieta e Localização na Infância e Adolescência, daqui em diante chamado de QDL. O referido questionário, apresentado no Apêndice D , contém perguntas discursivas e múltipla -escolha, e versa inicialmente sobre local de origem e migrações até os 18 anos de idade, em seguida sobre dieta na inf ância e adolescência, restrições alimentares, e perfil socioeconômico.

Dentre as informações iniciais se destacam sexo, data e local de nascimento e mobilidade residencial de 0 a 18 anos. A seção para registro de dieta na infância e adolescência possui ca mpos para registro de frequência aproximada de consumo dos seguintes alimentos, em campos separados: arroz, derivados de trigo, mandioca e inhame; milho e derivados; carne bovina ou suína; carne de frango; peixe e sua origem – água salgada ou doce –; leite e derivados; e açúcar e derivados da cana. Todos os campos de frequência alimentar aproximada foram divididos em subseções para o período de 9 a 14 anos, e de 15 a 18 anos, pois a metodologia inicial propunha como critério de inclusão molares, exceto o pr imeiro, ainda que houvesse suspeita por parte da equipe de que a maioria da amostra seria de terceiros molares, por razões já comentadas. O QDL inclui também em suas informações registradas a origem da água ingerida nestes períodos – encanada ou poço artes iano –, origem principal dos alimentos – feiras e vendas locais, supermercados e/ou produção familiar – e restrições alimentares, como alergias, diabetes, intolerância à lactose, e opções pessoais, incluindo veganos e vegetarianos, com campo para maior det alhamento sobre a restrição e sua cronologia. O perfil socioeconômico dos sujeitos teve campo resumido com número de coabitantes, grau de formação do responsável e renda familiar aproximada , o que permite avaliar a distribuição da amostra entre os estratos sociais , e a relação deste dado com o acesso aos diferentes alimentos pesquisados . Buscou -se, assim, tornar este trabalho potencialmente comparável a pesquisas arqueológicas anteriores baseadas em reconstrução da dieta a partir de análise isotópica e distribuição do a limento entre a população estudada. Por fim, registrou -se também a origem das informações – do próprio sujeito da pesquisa, ou de parente, com especificação.

Foram recebidos kits de QDL e dente(s) de 94 indivíduos, totalizando 130 dentes, pois em diversos casos, mais de um elemento dentário do mesmo paciente foi enviado. Dos 94 indivíduos, 19 foram excluídos, por terem nascido e/ou residido fora de uma das três cidades -alvo durante a mineralização do dente doado. Dos 75 casos incluídos na amostra, três amostras de esmalte e três amostras de dentina foram excluídas, pois, segundo relatado pelos sujeit os, na época em que parte dos elementos dentários se formou, não residiam em uma das cidades -alvos. O perfil da amostra encontra -se detalhado na sessão de resultados do artigo apresentado a seguir.
8.4 SELEÇÃO DE CASOS ESPECIAIS

Previamente ao preparo das amostras, as respostas ao QDL foram estudadas quanto à localização na infância e adolescência, para aplicação dos critérios de exclusão. Aqueles que migraram para outros estados ou vieram de outros estados durante a formação do dente doado, tiveram exc luídas a porção dentária que se formou em outro local. Desta forma, alguns dentes tiveram coroa, raiz, ou ápice radicular removidos da amostra. Indivíduos com dietas diferenciadas e restrições alimentares foram marcados como casos especiais, que incluíram vegetarianos, diabéticos e intolerantes à lactose.
8.5 TRATAMENTO DOS ELEMENTOS DENTÁRIOS E PREPARO DAS AMOSTRAS

Conforme solicitado aos cirurgiões -dentistas colaboradores, os dentes foram recebidos secos, em envelope plástico etiquetado com identifica ção do paciente, para que pudessem ser associados ao seu referente QDL. Os dentes eram embalados logo após sua extração e secagem, e, nenhum procedimento adicional foi solicitado aos profissionais. Uma vez recebidos em levas de 8 a 30 conjuntos de TCLE, QD L, e dente embalado, cada conjunto recebeu um código alfanumérico, com letras para as cidades, e números corridos para os pa rticipantes . As informações contidas nos QDLs preenchidos foram transcritas para uma planilha codificadas, e transformando classific ações como “nunca”, “raramente”, “às vezes”, “frequentemente” e “diariamente” em gradações numéricas (Excel, Microsoft , EUA) .

Os elementos então foram removidos do envelope plástico ( Figura 12) e limpos para remoção de restos de tecido, cálculo e sangue a deridos, com aparelho de ultrassom (Dabi Atlante, Ribeirão Preto -SP) e cureta periodontal ( Figura 13). Em seguida, os elementos foram secos com gaze, e armazenados em novo envelope plástico etiquetado e codificado.
(nome da paciente ocultado por tarja branca).
de ultrassom e irrigação ativada, em ambiente clínico, adequado para manipulação de material biológico.

Para remoção do esmalte, foi utilizada ponta diamantada esférica PM -06 (KG Sorensen, São Paulo, Brasil) , desgastando o dente em sulco raso – sem alcançar dentina – localizado entre o centro e a cervical da coroa, circundando -a (Figura s 14 e 15). O esmalte desta forma pulverizado, foi reunido em papel inerte descartável, para ser acondicionado em microtubo codificado, contendo ao menos 15mg de esmalte de cada dente. ( Figura 16).
sulco que circunda a coroa.
menos 15mg de esmalte de cada dente.

Em seguida o dente foi seccionado abaixo da linha cervical (Figura 17), com disco diamantado (KG Sorensen, São Paulo, Brasil), e do conduto radicular foi removido o tecido mole (Figura s 18 e 19) com limas endodônticas Hedstroem (Dentisply, Rio de Janeiro, Brasil) . As raízes foram igualmente acondicionadas em microtubos, até a finalizaçã o desta fase. Ao longo de todo o preparo das amostras, em cada etapa acima descrita, foram observadas todas as regras de biossegurança, considerando inclusive o manejo de material biológico, e seus riscos ocupacionais inerentes.

Para a extração d o colágeno , as raízes foram imersas, após pesagem, em NaOH 0,1M por 24 horas, para neutralização de ácidos húmicos. Em seguida, após enxague com água destilada, iniciou -se imersão em HCl 0,2M por sete dias (Figura 2 0), com substituição do HCl a cada 24 horas, e corte do material em pequenos pedaços para aumento da superfície de contato (Figura 2 1). Após enxague, as amostras foram imersas em uma solução de clorofórmio, metanol e água (2:1:0,8), para remoção de resíduos lipídeos, durante 24 horas. Os pseudomorfos de colágeno foram então enxaguados, e em seguida secos durante cerca de 8 horas em estufa a 50°C (Figura 2 2). Os fragmentos maiores foram reduzidos (Figura 2 3), para facilitar na seleção exata das alíquotas para os cadinhos de estanho, previamente à leitura em espectrômetro de massa.
secaram em estufa a 50º C durante cerca de 12 horas.

As análises de δ13C e δ18O foram realizadas em um Kiel IV Carbonate acoplado a um espectrômetro de massa MAT 253 da Thermo Scientific no laboratório de Geocronologia da Universidade de Brasília. Para análise, 1 mg de cada amostra de esmalte foi colocada no auto -sampler do Kiel I V Carbonate (Figura 2 4). Os valores de δ13C são apresentados em PDB, tendo -se utilizado padrões NBS18, NBS19 para verificação da acurácia e reprodutibilidade das determinações.
Para as an álises de δ13C e δ15N de colágeno foram pesadas alíquotas entre 500 e
650µg de cada amostra em cadinhos de estanho (Figura 2 5) para leitura em um

espectrômetro de massas, que foram introduzidas n o amostrador automático Thermo Scientific MAS 200R ; o N2 e CO 2 resultantes das amostras foram então enviados para a fonte de íons do Thermo Scientific Delta V IRMS onde foram ionizados e acelerados.
Geodinâmicos e Ambientais – UnB – e “empacotado” no cadinho de estanho.

Para as análises de estrôncio, cerca de 20 mg de cada amostra foi pesada e transferida para um béquer de tef lon, no qual se inicia o tratamento químico por meio da adição de 2ml de ácido nítrico concentrado (14N). As amostras foram digeridas a frio em cerca de uma hora e meia. Posteriormente, uma alíquota de 2ml de cada amostra foi colocada num micro -tubo de 2ml Eppendorf para centrifugação por 10 minutos. Após a centrifugação, uma alíquota de 1 ml dessa solução foi transferida para recipiente de teflon e levada para chapa quente até evaporação total da fase ácida. Após a evaporação, retom ou-se o resíduo com a ad ição de 5ml de ácido nítrico a 3% e determin ou-se a razão isotópica por espectrômetro de massa multicoletor com plasma acoplado (Neptune, Thermo Scientific) do Instituto de Geociências da UnB (Figura 2 6).
8.6 PROCESSAMENTO DOS DADOS OBTIDOS

Os dados obtidos foram tabulados em planilhas de Excel (Microsoft, Washington, EUA) e Statistical Package for the Social Sciences – SPSS – (IBM, Nova Iorque, EUA), para testes estatísticos e geração de gráficos e tabelas. Demais estudos que tenham analisado material arqueológico de Santa Catarina e do Rio de Janeiro (BASTOS et al., 2014; BASTOS, 2009, 2015; BASTOS et al., 2016; COLO NESE et al., 2014; DE MASI, 2001, 2009a; OPPITZ, 2015) foram utilizados para comparação e análise de metadados , bem como outros estudos de cunho forense voltados à identificação humana (ALKASS et al., 2011, 2013; JUAREZ, 2008; KAMENOV, 2008; KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017; WARNER et al., 2018) .

Os dados referentes aos valores isotópicos de 87Sr, 13C, 18O do esmalte, e de 13C, 15N e razão C:N do colágeno das amostras preparadas foram fornecidos pela equipe do Laboratório de Estudos Geodinâmicos e Ambien tais, da Universidade de Brasília. Os dados referentes ao estrôncio e aos valores isotópicos de carbono e nitrogênio do colágeno foram trabalhados mediante estatística descritiva e inferencial . Foram realizados testes de comparação de médias com ANOVA , pos teriormente à análise do teste de Levene, e seguido de Pós -teste de Tukey . Após verificação da confiabilidade das variáveis dependentes , testada através de análise de covariância com arquivos divididos , foi realizada a nálise linear multivariável (MANOVA) tendo como variáveis dependentes 13C, 15N e 87Sr/86Sr, e amostra como fator fixo . Verificou -se ainda a correlação entre as variáveis através do teste de correlação de Pearson , além de comparação entre os dados obtidos por estudos anteriores, forenses e ar queológicos.
9 ARTIGO “ISOTOPIC ANALYSIS IN TEETH OF CONTEMPORARY BRAZILIANS WITH KNOWN DIET AND GEOLOCATION AND ITS VALUE FOR FORENSIC HUMAN IDENTIFICATION ”

Isotopic analysis in teeth of contemporary Brazilians with known diet and geolocation and its value for forensic human identification Rachel Lima Ribeiro Tinoco1, Murilo Quintans Ribeiro Bastos2, Carlos Eduardo Palhares Machado3, Roberto Ventura4, Claudia Rodrigues -Carvalho5

1 Programa de Pós -Graduação em Arqueologia, Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro 2 Departamento de Antropologia, Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro 3 Instituto Nacional de Criminalística, Departamento de Polícia Federal 4 [Dados do Prof. Roberto], Universidade de Brasília 5 Departamento de Antropologia, Museu Nacional, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro

Abstract Dental anthropological data can inform about many aspects such as the age at death, health, sign s of violence, ancestry, diet features, intentional modifications, and geographic origin. Isotopic analysis can provide data about diet and residential mobility. However, the use of the method in a modern population requires an updated and location - specifi c database. The aim of the present paper was to evaluate the isotopic ratio of strontium, carbon and nitrogen of enamel and dentin collagen of third molars of subjects from three cities in different regions of Brazil, with known data including diet in adolescence in order to expand models for exploration of the method in archaeological and forensic context in Brazilian territory. The forensic value of the place of origin estimation through 87Sr/86Sr levels was shown to be reduced in these highly urbanized samples. Among the outliers, individuals older than the mean age (25.1) and those who reported well water consumption in adolescence were the most frequent cases. The sample's diet has a strong C4 presence and mean trophic levels as found in terrestrial diets, which is consistent with the high frequency of chicken, meat and dairy products declared, together with the high sugar intake and widespread consumption of rice and beans, belonging to the local culture . People with special diets, either by choice or therapeutic needs were potential outliers among the group. Keywords: forensic sciences, dental anthropology, stable isotopes, strontium, diet, geolocation, forensic anthropology

When analyzing the arch of a skeletal remain, one can infer the age at death, general health, signs of violence, biological distance from other groups, oral pathologies, mainly caries and periodontal disease, and diet features, such as food sharing, distance from the shore, habits, intentional modifications, and cultural even ts, mostly rituals, frequently affecting anterior teeth (HILLSON, 1996; KOUSSOULAKOU; MARGARITIS; KOUSSOULAKOS, 2009; SCOTT; TURNER, 2000) . The same information can be explored both in archaeological and forensic contexts, with the addition of all feasible therapeutic and aesthetic procedures in contemporary groups. The information content in dental records composes the antemortem data and includes forms, notes, image exams, models of plaster, and photographs (CHARANGOWDA, 2010; DELATTRE, 2007; PRETTY; SWEE T, 2001).

Isotopic analysis is an auxiliary method used initially in archeology, and later for the forensic sciences broadly. Some of the most commonly used elements are carbon, nitrogen, oxygen and strontium, and their isotopic ratios from different tissu es such as bones, teeth, hair and nails are directly related to dietary characteristics and individual location, always considering the period of cell formation. Thus, by comparing different tissues, researchers can obtain different anthropological data of great use for human identification.

However, for the forensic use of the method aimed at human identification, it is essential to have international databases obtained from contemporary population samples of hair, nails and teeth (KAMENOV et al., 2014). T he multicenter availability of isotopic data such as carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, lead and strontium would allow tissue analysis of an unidentified corpse and enhance the chances of estimation of place of origin, residential mobility, and diet particularities .

Regarding strontium isotopes, the ratio of 87Sr/86Sr present in rocks and soils varies according to the age of geological formation, as well as the amount of rubidium – an element that decays and originates 87Sr. This 87Sr/86Sr ratio of local geology ent ers the biosphere as it is assimilated through nutrients and water by plants and animals without changing its proportion. Thus, humans absorbing food and water from a given location acquire a specific isotopic signature of 87Sr/86Sr, which may be useful fo r studying their provenance (BUDD et al., 2004; FAURE, 1986) .

Strontium is very similar to calcium and has similar behavior in the body, even replacing it partially in the hydroxyapatite crystals of enamel and bone tissue. Thus, when analyzing the 87Sr/86Sr ratio present in bone, it is possible to debate about geological formation of the place where the individual obtained his or her food and water in the last years, when the bone was remodeled. Using the same procedure in dental enamel, the 87Sr/86Sr ratio will provide data referring to the geolocation in childhood or adolescence, according to the chronology of tooth mineralization used for analysis, because dental enamel forms in the first decades of life and is never remodeled. Combining the results of different tissues allows study residential mobility, with effect on demographic, pathological, cultural, social, and forensic features(BENTLEY et al., 2003; KAMENOV; CURTIS, 2017; KATZENBERG, 2008; PRICE; BURTON; BENTLEY, 2002).

The isotopic values of δ13C are directly related to diet composition, being relevant the presence of plants C3 (as potato, beans, wheat and rice) or C4 (maize, sorghum and sugar cane). However, marine food has values superimposed to C4 plants (FRY, 2008; KATZENBERG, 2008; MEIER -AUGENSTEIN, 2010a) , since their carbon source includes CO2 and bicarbonate dissolved in the water and debris from the terrestrial flora. The usual diet composition, including the amount of marine species, C3 and C4 plants, and protein from animals fed by these species directly influence in the isotopic ratio of
13C that will be present in human tissues (HOWLAND et al., 2003; KELLNER;

SCHOENINGER, 2007; LEE -THORP; VAN DER MERWE, 1991; SCHOENINGER; Nitrogen isotopes are also related to the diet , however, the δ15N values varies according to the trophic level of the individual, increasing between 2 and 6‰ at each stage of the food chain (SCHWARCZ; SCHOENINGER, 1991). Thus, carnivores have values of δ15N higher than herbivores, which in turn have h igher values than plants and other autotrophic organisms (O’CONNELL; HEDGES, 1999; SCHOENINGER; DENIRO, 1984a; SCHWARCZ; SCHOENINGER, 1991) . The nitrogen isotopic analysis, therefore, is an important tool for the study of the food chains of different regio ns. When combining carbon and nitrogen analysis it is possible to differentiate diets rich in C4 plants from those rich in marine animals, solving the previously reported issue caused by the overlap of carbon values between food sources(BASTOS et al., 2015 ). On studying tooth elements, the collagen extracted from the dentin presents values of 13C and 15N related to the protein component of the diet, while the d13C from the carbonate, usually extracted from the hydroxyapatite shows the average of all carbon sources ingested (BASTOS et al., 2015; BURT; AMIN, 2014) .

Considering the resistance of teeth and bones to decomposition, and their archaeological and forensic importance, one can highlight the value of the method described. Isotopic analysis provides ins ight into diet and residential mobility, including their oscillations and derived features, information that may be of great value to know a group, or to identify a single individual. However, the use of the method in a modern population requires an update d and location -specific database(ALKASS et al., 2011, 2013; JUAREZ, 2008; KAMENOV et al., 2014; WARNER et al., 2018).

The aim of the present paper is to evaluate the isotopic ratio of strontium, carbon and nitrogen of enamel and dentin collagen of third m olars of subjects from three cities of different regions in Brazil. The evaluation composed by isotopic analysis and anthropological data such as age, gender, residential mobility, habitual diet and socioeconomic features in adolescence aim to expand model s for the exploration of the method in archaeological and forensic context in Brazilian territories. By exploring the method in the opposite direction to that practiced archaeologically, the authors intend to validate it from a known framework, to investig ate the relationship with the obtained isotopic profile, possible regional “isotopic signatures”, and effects of modern life on the applicability of the method.

Material and methods Sampling The sample consisted of healthy third molars of individuals from Brasília, Florianópolis and Rio de Janeiro, three Brazilian cities separated by distances from 744 to 1,316km (Figure 27). Subjects with third molar extraction planned for dental reasons unrelated to the research were invited to participate by donating their teeth and filling out a questionnaire about diet and residence from childhood to youth.
Figure 27 – Location and linear distance between the selected target -cities – Brasília, Rio de Ja neiro and Florianópolis (Source: Google Maps).

The teeth were included in the sample respecting the following criteria: Brazilian nationality, minimum age of 14 years, place of birth and residence in one of the target cities, healthy third molar donated. T he material received totaled 139 teeth of 94 individuals. After applying the selection criteria, teeth of 19 individuals were totally excluded and partial exclusions involved three crowns and two roots; one third molar was selected from each subject , provi ding a final sample of 75 subjects . It is not possible to specify the number of patients who denied to participate, since the researchers counted on the collaboration of five dental surgeons coordinating postgraduate surgery courses, who invited patients t hat fit the inclusion criteria without recording rejection.

Complementary data collection The Questionnaire on Diet and Geolocation in Adolescence (QDGA) contained discursive and multiple -choice questions, focusing on place of birth and residential mobility up to the age of 18, diet habits, dietary restrictions, and socioeconomic features as education and monthly income. The section for diet registration included separate fields for recording the approximate frequency of consumption of th e following items: rice, wheat derivatives, cassava and yam; corn and derivatives; beef or pork; chicken meat; fish and their origin - salted or sweet water; milk and milk products; and sugar and sugar cane derivatives. Each participant estimated how often they used to ingest each item, using the categories "never", "rarely", "occasionally", "frequently" or "daily". Each category was coded with a value from 0 to 4, respectively. Regarding sugar, the participants chose the approximate amount of sugar intake, with the options "none", "little", "average" and "a lot", which also were coded with numerical values from 0 to 3. Participants were asked about their usual diet during adolescence, at which age the third molars were in formation. There was, therefore, a limitation in the use of detailed and standardized nutritional questionnaires, which use recent memory, and record ingested content with a 24hs recall. With the estimated frequency of intake of the food groups, the authors admit a limitation on the specifi city of the information provided, generated by memory bias. The questionnaire also extracted information about water source, main source of food, and possible dietary restrictions, such as allergies, diabetes, lactose intolerance, and personal options, inc luding vegans and vegetarians, with a detailed description of the restriction and its chronology.

Sample preparation After removing calculus and cleaning the teeth with a periodontal curette (SS White Duflex, Rio de Janeiro) and ultrasound device (Dabi At lante, Ribeirão Preto, SP), the elements were dried with gauze and stored in a coded plastic envelope. The enamel was removed with diamond tip PM -06 (KG Sorensen, São Paulo, Brazil), wearing out a shallow groove around it, on the cervical half of the crown , being conditioned in a microtube with at least 20mg of enamel.

For collagen extraction, the roots were immersed in NaOH 0.1M for 24 hours, to neutralize humus acid. After rinsing with distilled water, immersion was started in HCl 0.2M for seven days, wit h daily replacement of HCl, and cutting the material into small pieces to increase the contact surface. After rinsing, the samples were immersed for 24 hours in a solution of chloroform, methanol and water (2:1:0.8) to remove lipid residues. The collagen p seudomorphs were then rinsed and dried for about 8 hours in an oven at

Isotopic analyzes For analyzes of δ13C and δ15N of collagen, aliquots between 500 and 650μg of each sample were weighed in tin crucibles for measurement in a mass spectrometer, which were introduced in the automatic sampler Thermo Scientific MAS 200R; the N 2 and CO 2 resulting from the samples were then sent to the ion source of Thermo Scientific Delta V IRMS where they were ionized and accelerated. International reference standa rds IAEA601, NIST8542, UIW, USGS 41 were used.

For the strontium analyzes, about 20mg of each sample was weighed and transferred to a Teflon beaker, in which the chemical treatment was initiated by the addition of 2ml of concentrated nitric acid (14N). Sam ples were cold digested for about 90 minutes. A 2ml aliquot of each sample was placed in a 2ml Eppendorf micro -tube for centrifugation for 10 minutes. Then, a 1 ml aliquot of this solution was transferred to a Teflon vessel and brought to a hot plate until total evaporation of the acid phase. The residue was taken up with the addition of 5 ml of 3% nitric acid and the isotope ratio was determined by multiplier mass spectrometer with coupled plasma (Neptune, Thermo Scientific), withstandard NIST SRM 987.

Data treatment Data were tabulated in Excel spreadsheets (Microsoft, Washington, USA) and Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) (IBM, New York, USA) for statistical tests and generation of charts and tables. The data were evaluated using descript ive and inferential statistics: normality test (Shapiro -Wilk) and means comparison tests (Student's T-test, MANOVA test). After the analysis of the Levene test, and after the result was generated, the Tukey Post -test was performed. Pearson's correlation te st was also performed and, in cases where there was a statistically significant correlation between the variables, Linear Regression analysis was performed sequentially to verify the relationship between these variables and the coefficient of determination of age in function of the 87Sr/86Sr ratio and 15N values found. All tests were performed on IBM SPSS Software (22.0), using a significance level of 5%.

Ethical aspects The research project was submitted to ethical appraisal to the Committee of Ethics Research from the Center for Philosophy and Human Sciences of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro. The project was approved by report number 1,561,481.

Discussion The diet compositio n is the main determinant of the isotopic values of carbon and nitrogen in the tissue structure. The dentin collagen presents values of 13C and 15N based on the source of protein intake. These values vary in 15N according to the trophic
87Sr/86Sr Loca tions

level of th e protein, and in 13C according to the amount of C3 or C4 vegetal species consumed at the base of the food chain (BEAUMONT; MONTGOMERY, 2016; SCHOENINGER; DENIRO, 1984a) . Researchers who use isotopic analyses as a tool can focus on changes in food sources, allowing inference of the demographic dynamics, resource origin, food sharing, and new food insertion into distinct groups, among others (BEAUMONT et al., 2013; BENSON et al., 2006a; BOURBOU et al., 2013; EERKENS Forensic investigations aimed at human identification can use isotopic analyses as an auxiliary tool, with the potential to differentiate food profiles, focusing on 13C and 15N, and of geographic origin, when exploring the ratio 87Sr/86Sr, influenced by local geology. Analyzed from different tissues, the isotopic values can provide information of different periods, according to the tissue formation chronology, allowing the investigation of geograph ic origin, residential mobility, and food changes. Among these, dental enamel and dentin collagen provide dietary e geographic data about childhood and adolescence, since they are the only tissues that do not remodel (FONT et al., 2012, 2015; KAMENOV; CURT IS, 2017) . The isotopic analysis in a forensic and contemporary context shall count on current and local databases, which are the aim of this paper.

From the sample of 75 third molars of individuals who declared their usual diet in adolescence, there was n o significant difference in ratios of 87Sr/86Sr between the Rio de Janeiro and Brasília groups, and in 13C values among all sample groups. There were significant correlations (Sig. <0.05) between age and 15N, age and 87Sr/86Sr ratio, sample group and 15N, and 15N and 87Sr/86Sr. A combined analysis of 13C and 15N suggests strong C4 presence in the protein base and trophic level compatible to a terrestrial diet; however, there was no significant difference concerning usual diet. Among outlier cases, the age above group average was the most common feature, besides cases of well water consumption and food restrictions, especially lactose intolerance.

In Brazil, public policies for social inclusion in the last decades have succeeded in reducing poverty and malnutrition, especially between 1996 and 2007. However, changes in the patterns of the Brazilian diets have resulted in nutritional transition, raising the frequency of overweight and obesity to three times higher than that of malnutrition (CONDE; MONTEIR O, 2014). With changes in socioeconomic context and increases in per capita income, consumption and relevance of industrialized and ultra -processed foods have increased in Brazilian diets. These foods have twice as much free sugar as in natura foods, and i nclude crackers, snacks, soda, cereal bars, instant noodles, dehydrated soups, and ready or semi -ready meals. Recent researches indicate that ultra -processed foods represent 21.5% of total energy intake. Among in natura or minimally processed foods, rice a nd beans are the most frequently consumed, accounting for 22.9% of energy intake. In this same group, red meat, milk, poultry, and fish represent 10.0, 5.4, 4.9, and 1.7% respectively (LOUZADA et al., 2015). The products with the highest daily consumption among the analyzed sample were "rice, wheat and derivatives, cassava or yam" (53.3%), and "milk and derivatives" (51.4%), according to the questionnaire. The authors also observed frequent or daily consumption of “beef or pork” (80%) and “chicken meat” Important variations in indicators of food household availability were observed in the metropolitan areas of the country in the period from 1974 -2003, with a decline in the consumption of staple foods such as rice and beans, and an increase in the co nsumption of beef (+ 22%), chicken meat (+ 100%), sausages (+ 300%), milk and dairy products (+ 36%), biscuits and soft drinks (+ 400%) and ready -to-eat meals (+ 80%) (LEVY -COSTA et al., 2005). This food profile matches the results found from the combined analysis of 13C and 15N, with a strong C4 presence and mean trophic levels as found in terrestrial diets, which is consistent with the high frequency of chicken, meat and dairy products, together with high sugar intake and widespread consumption of rice and beans, belonging to the local culture. Although most of the subjects surveyed reported an average amount of ingested sugar (55.4%), this data can be underestimated since commercial products containing sugar were not specified or exe mplified and may not have been considered by the participant when responding.

Literature on the changes in the Brazilian diet agrees about the growth of ultra - processed food industry, and the increased presence of these products in the usual diet, especial ly soft drinks, biscuits, general candies, and ready -to-eat meals (CONDE; MONTEIRO, 2014; FEFERBAUM; DE ABREU; LEONE, 2012; LEVY -COSTA et al., 2005; LOUZADA et al., 2015; MONTEIRO et al., 2010; SOUZA et al., 2013). This change endorses the hypothesis of nu tritional transition related to urbanization, with increased consumption of processed and pre -prepared foods in response to the increasing work demand. The presence of subjects with food restriction among outliers suggests a hypothesis of lower consumption of industrialized and ultra -processed products, often avoided by those with restrictive diets, due to hidden and undesirable ingredients such as sugar, dyes, gluten and lactose. Thereby, isotopic analysis would be a possible tool in helping to identify in dividuals with special diets. The forensic value of this analysis can be confirmed and measured from new research with representative samples of omnivores, vegetarians, vegans, lactose intolerants, diabetics, and other types of food restrictions. The wide industrialization recently observed in food production and consumption in Brazil should also be considered as a contributing factor to the correlation found between age, 87Sr/86Sr and 15N, since younger individuals tend to consume food items produced in m ore distant places, and had higher consumption of meat and processed products during the mineralization of their dental elements. Participants with ages above the sample average, in turn, had a greater presence of local products in their diet, and lower me at and sugar consumption observed in the general population, at the formation time of the studied teeth. The secondary dentin layer, with its continuous lifelong apposition that makes its relative portion directly proportional to the individual's age, shou ld also be considered a remote hypothesis. Thus, this layer of dentin, used as a parameter for age estimation (CAMERIERE et al., 2013), contains elements related to diet throughout adult life, and not only in childhood, as can be affirmed in relation to primary dentin. Future studies with representative samples of different age groups would be useful to measure the effect of secondary dentin on the collagen values 13C and 15N. This possible bias, once known and measured, must be considered in every isotop ic research that includes adult teeth, which are, in most archaeological contexts, the only available material.

Other aspects related to the country's socioeconomic development and its relationship with the population's food profile include the livestock g rowth. Through commercial relations policies such as Mercosur, and economic measures of the last decades, there was a modernization of the sector, development of new technologies, research centers, production segmentation, raising the country to the posit ion of the world's largest commercial herd. Consequently, it was seen a significant reduction of cattle imports, and an increase in per capita consumption(POLAQUINI; SOUZA; GEBARA, 2006), as agreed by nutritional literature (LEVY -COSTA et al., 2005; LOUZAD A et al., 2015). Analyzed against the results of the present study, these factors corroborate the limitation of the accuracy of strontium values as a possible indicator of city of origin.

Since the analysis of 13C and 15N relates to the diet composition, and especially to C3 and C4 plant species at the base of the food chain, the agricultural evolution and expansion of food production and distribution networks should be carefully considered when analyzing a modern sample. Along with the growing demand for food and the changes in socioeconomic context, the development of the Brazilian agricultural industry during the last decades has brought meaningful evolution in different aspects such as market, consumption, production, research and technology. One could also mention the emergence of producer centers, new techniques of crop optimization (SATTERTHWAITE; MCGRANAHAN; TACOLI, 2010), geoprocessing, genetic modification and soil fertilization. As for fertilizing, the use of organic or chemical products - employ ed by 30.8% of the establishments (IBGE) - is particularly relevant when changing nitrogen fixation (ROSOLEM; FOLONI; OLIVEIRA, 2003; VIEIRA FILHO; FISHLOW, 2017). Land use and the change in the proportion of planting and pasture area in relation to native soil also cause significant differences in the concentrations of elements such as carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus (GROPPO et al., The economic growth modifies the relation between agriculture and major urban centers, and the way the food goes fro m field to table, with greater participation of supermarkets and food distribution networks (SATTERTHWAITE; MCGRANAHAN; TACOLI, 2010). As observed in the present study 81.33% of the sample have reported purchasing products from supermarkets, and only 10.66 % declared participation of family production, among which 4% have this as the only food source.

The water supply system brought by urbanization tends to reduce the accuracy of strontium as a residence indicator, since consumers in a large geographical ar ea will have access to the same source of drinking water. This buffer effect of the supply system is a possible hypothesis for the highlight found in well water consumers, common among outliers.

Water supply served for 63.9% of households in Brazil in 200 0, and 78.6% in 2008, when most of the research subjects were in the period of formation of their third molars. However, this value is not equally distributed in all states, being higher for the Southeast region, where Rio de Janeiro is located – 70.5% in 2000, and 87.5% in 2008. The next mentioned is the South region, where Florianópolis is located, appearing with 69.1% in 2000 and 84.2% in 2008, and the center -west region, where Brasília is located, with 66.3% (2000) and 82.0% (2008) (INSTITUTO BRASILEIRO DE GEOGRAFIA E ESTATÍSTICA (IBGE), 2010) . This buffering effect of the supply system can be considered as a hypothesis for the prominence found among well water consumers, and older people, common among outliers.

The comparative analysis of the 87Sr/86Sr v alues did not show a significant difference between the groups from Brasília and Rio de Janeiro, different from the expected due to their position regarding the coast. Both regions have formations with close geo -chronologies, which does not imply having th e same proportion of rubidium. One must also consider also the remarkable presence of marine strontium in Rio de Janeiro.

Although these values were not specific and with isotopic signature among the target cities, comparing the sample as a single group in relation to international data showed a significant difference between the Brazilian sample and all other groups, including the USA and Mexico - neighboring countries with contemporary data available in the literature. This finding reaffirms the forensic value of the technique as a possible auxiliary method in the human identification process, since a Mexican individual, for example, would be readily found among multiple human remnants in Brazil.

The use of isotopic analysis as an auxiliary resource for hu man identification requires regularly updated databases from local population samples. These values, however, are sensitive to the degree of urbanization, agricultural dynamics, water supply system, trade relations, local culture, and personal preferences. Therefore, relevant data to isotopic values must be recorded from the selected sample, such as age, income, water source, possible dietary restrictions and habitual diet at the time of formation of the analyzed tissue.

Conclusions The forensic value of the place of origin estimation through 87Sr/86Sr levels was shown to be reduced in the highly urbanized sample as the one selected for the study. Among the outliers, individuals older than the mean age and those who reported well wate r consumption in adolescence were the most frequent cases. The discriminant function analysis considering the values of 87Sr/86Sr and δ15N obtained a success rate in sample group prediction of 63.2%. The method can also be used as an auxiliary resource in the investigation of place of origin, which presents accuracy in distinguishing individuals from distant places, as seen in the comparison of the group with international samples.

According to the isotopic ratios of carbon and nitrogen found in collagen, the sample's diet has an important C4 component and high trophic level, which is consistent with the high consumption of red meat, amount of sugar in industrialized products, and increasing intake of chicken meat, as reported in the literature. People wit h special diets, either by choice or therapeutic needs were potential outliers among the group, which can be interpreted as greater control of consumed industrialized products, and less average distance between subject and food's point of origin.

The autho rs suggest new research to verify the effect of urbanization, diet industrialization, and water supply on isotopic indicators, and to evaluate the forensic accuracy of these tools in groups of different locations, degrees of urbanization, ages, and dietary compositions. In cases of human identification, a peculiar dietary profile, whether by choice or therapy, such as vegan, vegetarian, allergic, bulimic or anorexic can be an important individualizing feature, increasing chances of success. Therefore, indiv iduals within these groups or with migration history should be studied to evaluate the accuracy of isotopic analysis in these cases. Among the 139 teeth received at the beginning of the present paper, some special cases were selected for further investigat ions, which could not be performed due to the loss of the material during the fire at the National Museum, Rio de Janeiro.

Os valores de 18O se distribuíram entre -7,34 e -3,74, com média de -6,00, e desvio padrão de 0,63 . Não houve diferença estatisticamente significante entre as amostras de Brasília, Florianópolis e Rio de Janeiro. A Figura 33 mostra o gráfico de dispersão dos valores encontrados, identificados os outliers. Dentre estes, dois indivíduos relataram abastecimento por água de poço e vendas locais, sem consumo em supermercados (casos 2 e 64) , o caso 68 alegou ter se mudado aos 12 ano s, e o caso 37 declarou restrição a sal a partir dos 10 anos.

A título de comparação, os valores de 18O de águas subterrâneas do Distrito Federal variam entre -5,71‰ e -5,19‰, os quais equivalem à média global do vapor atmosférico e precipitação nos oceano s (LOUSADA; CAMPOS, 2011) . Esta diferença em relação à média de -6,08 encontrada na amostra de Brasíli a permite apontar o foco para a importância da dieta como fator a ser investigado em pesquisas para construção de bancos de dados para análise isotópica. A origem do peixe presente na dieta e sua frequência de ingestão também pode ser observada frente esta pequena oscilação do grupo de Florianópolis , com todos os casos de presença de peixe na dieta com origem marinha, ao contrário de 70,6% de peixes de água doce consumidos pelos participantes de Brasília. Entretanto, a amostra reduzida limita esta interpret ação e sugere novas e amplas investigações sobre o tema.

A média d e 13C da hidroxiapatita foi de -9,06 (entre -10,76 e -7,40) e o desvio padrão de 0,7 9. Estes valores, da mesma maneira, não mostraram diferença estatística entre os diferentes grupos estudados (Figur a 34), o que corrobora com o quadro encontrado a partir do questionário.

Os indivíduos incluídos na amostra relataram dieta onívora com componente terrestre predominante, padrão alimentar muito semelhante, grande participação de supermercados no abaste cimento doméstico (81,33% da amostra) e consumo de produtos industrializados. A literatura sobre as mudanças na dieta brasileira concorda com o crescimento da indústria de alimentos ultraprocessados e com o aumento da presença desses produtos na dieta habi tual, principalmente refrigerantes, biscoitos, doces em geral

e refeições prontas (CONDE; MONTEIRO, 2014; FEFERBAUM; DE ABREU; LEONE, 2012; LEVY -COSTA et al., 2005; LOUZADA et al., 2015; MONTEIRO et al., 2010; SOUZA et al., 2013). Essa mudança endossa a hi pótese de mudanças nutricionais relacionadas à urbanização, com aumento do consumo de alimentos congelados e redução de alimentos in natura , como observado por Nardoto et al . (2011 ) em populações amazônicas .
11 COTEJO D OS RESULTADOS E DADOS ARQUEOLÓGICOS PRÉVIOS
11.1 CONTEXTUALIZAÇÃO

Os resultados encontrados no presente estudo foram confrontados aos valores encontrados em pesquisas semelhantes feitas por outros pesquisadores ao analisarem dentes de remanescentes humanos de sítios arqueológicos do Rio de Janeiro e de Santa Catarina. Pretende -se, a partir de dados disponíveis na literatura, observar o comportamento deste dado bioarqueológico em grupos am ostrais contíguos geograficamente, porém separados por centenas de anos de história.

Os dados arqueológicos foram derivados de trabalhos recentes na literatura arqueológica, com remanescentes humanos dos sítios de Armação do Su l (OPPITZ, 2015) , Marechal Lu z (BASTOS et al., 2014) e Praia da Tapera (BASTOS et al., 2015) , no litoral de Santa Catarina, e dos sítios de Arapuã, Bananeiras, Beirada, Duna Grande de Itaipu, Ilhote do Leste, Moa, Pontinha, Sernambetiba, e Zé Espinho, no litoral do Rio de Janeiro (EMENES, 2019) .

O sítio Praia da Tapera, no sul de Florianópolis , localiza -se a 20km de Florianópolis, com três momentos de ocupação – duas associadas à tradição ceramista Itararé, datadas por radiocarbono com 1.140 ± 180 A.P. e 1.030 ± 180 A.P, e uma ocupação Tupiguarani datada em 550 ± 70 A.P. Os 172 sepultamentos humanos, todos associados às ocupações Itararé, concentravam -se em área de 608m2, e dividiam -se quanto à idade estimada, em 74 indivíduos com menos de 16 anos, 79 adultos, e 19 maduros (Neves 1984 – apud Bastos). Os valores isotópicos de carbono, nitrogênio e estrôncio sugerem dieta fortemente marinha, alguns deles com valores compatíveis a consumo de animais de alto nível trófico, como tubarão, lobo e leão marinho (BASTOS O síti o Armação do Sul, na costa catarinense, com extensão estimada de 2000m2 de área atualmente urbanizada foi datado, através dos 30 indivíduos encontrados nos 269m2 escavados, com duas camadas cronologicamente distintas, abrangendo no total 3065 a 1275 anos A P. As análises de estrôncio, carbono e nitrogênio referentes às duas camadas arqueológicas permitiram interpretação de mudanças ocorridas envolvendo maior circulação e incorporação de indivíduos de diferentes partes do litoral central; mudança na dieta dos indivíduos do sexo masculino quanto ao consumo de recursos C4 ou à redução do consumo de recursos marinhos de alto nível trófico; hierarquia social mais claramente observável no registro arqueológico, dentre outros dados antropológicos (OPPITZ, 2015) .

O sítio Forte Marechal Luz, ao norte do litoral de Santa Catarina, apresenta uma série de ocupações sem evidência de cerâmica, seguidas de ocupações com cerâmica com alguns momentos de abandono, entre os quatro milênios de ocupação, iniciados em 4.290 ± 130 a nos AP, segundo a datação mais antiga por 14C. Dos 65 remanescentes humanos encontrados, 42 estavam em camadas sem cerâmica, e 23 em estratos com presença de cerâmica. Os valores de carbono e nitrogênio apresentados por Bastos et al . (2014) mostram alterações na dieta nas camadas com cerâmica, com redução do consumo proteico de proveniência marinha . Estas diferenças sugerem, segundo o autor, dieta mais diversificada e com menor dependência de recursos marinhos, mas não permitem interp retar o aumento do consumo de vegetais como resultado de qualquer forma de horticultura (BASTOS et al., 2014) .

Os demais sítios, distribuídos no litoral do Rio de Janeiro, incluem Ilhote do Leste, Zé Espinho, Arapuã, Sernambetiba, Duna Grande de Itaipu, Mo a, Beirada, Pontinha e Bananeiras. Dentre estes, sete são considerados sambaquis, à exceção de Duna Grande de Itaipu, classificado como sítio em duna, e o Bananeiras um sítio Tupi. Os dados aqui comparados referem -se a um indivíduo de cada um dos sítios su pracitados e foram apresentados por Emenes. (2019) . A autora conclu iu que a forte influência do estrôncio marinho dificulta o uso desse método para o estudo de migração ao longo do litoral no estado. Entretanto, variações encontradas nos sítios Arapuã e Ba naneiras indicam possível análise de variação no eixo litoral -interior do estado do RJ.
11.2 RESULTADOS

A amostra contemporânea que foi usada para comparação com os dados arqueológicos citados foi composta por 40 indivíduos, de 27,2 (± 9,4) anos, com 17 (42,5%) homens e 23 (57,5%) mulheres , uma vez que foram considerados os grupos de Florianópolis e Rio de Janeiro, locais em que há dados arqueológicos a serem comparados . Quanto a dados socioeconômicos, a maioria (42,5%) da amostra possui ensino médio, e r enda mensal familiar aproximada de 2 a 5 salários mínimos (45,0%). A amostra de Florianópolis apresentou média de proporção isotópica 87Sr/86Sr de 0,7114 5 (±0,00055), enquanto, para o Rio de Janeiro, a média encontrada foi de 0,71221 (±0,00103). A comparação entre os grupos através de análise de variância (ANOVA) mostrou diferença estatística entre os valores de 87Sr/86Sr das amostras comparadas (p<0,001; R2=0.699). A dispersão dos valores referentes às amostras pode ser vista n a Figura 35 , consid erando todos os sítios fluminense como uma única amostra .

A comparação dos valores de 18O entre os grupos de Florianópolis e Rio de Janeiro em comparação aos remanescentes arqueológicos da mesma região mostrou diferença estatisticamente signifi cante, possibilitando visualizar a dispersão de 18O combinada com 87Sr/86Sr na Figura 36 .

Quando comparados os valores isotópicos de 13C e 15N, à guisa de exemplo, pode -se verificar as diferenças entre as dietas dos grupos arqueológicos e contemporâneos. Os remanescentes dos sítios arqueológicos de Santa Catarina com disponibilidade de dados de 13C e 15N sugerem dietas fortemente marinhas, com alimentos de alto nível trófico , e pouco componente terrestre. Os grupos contemporâneos, por sua vez, mostraram valores de 15N condizentes com dieta terrestre , tal qual relatado nos questionários, com alto consumo de frango, carne vermelha, arroz, leite e derivados , e pequena participação marinha (Figura 37). Os valores de 13C contemporâneos mais negativos que os encontrados nos grupos arqueológicos podem ser compreendidos pelo mesmo motivo, dad o o componente terrestre da dieta brasileira atual , diferente do quadro encontrado nos sambaquis comparados .
